aa

Class FormulaTree

  • java.lang.Object
    • aa.FormulaTree

  • public class FormulaTree
extends java.lang.Object
    Class for binary expression trees for formulas in first-order logic. Nodes exists for three quantifiers (∀, ∃, ∃!), five operators (&, v, ⊃, ≡, ¬) and arbitrary predicate expressions from the input domain (eg: P(x,y,z)). Variables are not represented as nodes, but are instead associated with their respective quantifier or predicate nodes. This class includes methods for creating, rewriting, and evaluating the truth-value of expression trees.

        Returns:
        a String representation of the formula

      • eliminateUniquenessQuantification

        public FormulaTree eliminateUniquenessQuantification()
        Eliminate uniqueness quantifier ∃! by tree rewriting. Calls the recursive method elimUniquenessRecurse().
        Returns:
        a logically equivalent FormulaTree lacking a uniqueness quantifier

      • elimUniquenessRecurse

        public FormulaTree elimUniquenessRecurse(java.util.Map<java.lang.Character,java.lang.Character> substitution)
        Recursive method for tree rewriting. Copies all tree nodes unchanged except for uniqueness quantifiers. Translates according to the equivalence ∃!xP(x) <-> ∃x∀t(P(t) <-> x=t)). In general, where S is any subtree, the expression "∃!xS" becomes ∃x∀t(S[x/t] <-> x=t))
        Parameters:
        substitution - a Java Map of variable substitutions
        Returns:
        A new tree without a uniqueness quantifier as the top node, with the given substitution applied

      • nullSubstitution

        public static java.util.Map<java.lang.Character,java.lang.Character> nullSubstitution()
        Create an initial substitution mapping for the eliminateUniquenessQuantification() method. This initial mapping has no effect, it maps x |-> x, y |-> y, etc. The mapping is altered where appropriate as elimUniquenessRecurse() recurses through the FormulaTree.
        Returns:
        an identity substitution where each variable is mapped to itself.

      • tupleSubstitution

        public static char[] tupleSubstitution(char[] oldTuple,
                       java.util.Map<java.lang.Character,java.lang.Character> substitution)
        Apply a given substitution to the variable tuple of a predicate. Given the substitution (x |-> t, y |-> u) and predicate term P(x,y,y), produces the new tuple (t,u,u) expressed as a character array. Any unsubstituted variables keep their original names.
        Parameters:
        oldTuple - a char array representing the variable tuple for a predicate term
        substitution - a mapping between variables
        Returns:
        the new variable tuple

        Parameters:
        oldVar - the old variable (one of x,y,z,w)
        Returns:
        a character representing a fresh varaible

      • numVars

        public int numVars()
        Computes the number of variables in a term. Returns zero for invalid ranges. Calls numVarsForThisRange()
        Returns:
        the integer number of variables

      • numVarsForThisRange

        public static int numVarsForThisRange(byte range)
        Static method to compute the number of variables in an expression, where the input is a variable range value encoded as a Java byte. Each of the four possible variables is given a binary value:

        x = 1000

        y = 0100

        z = 0010

        w = 0001

        The variables present in an expression are summed together, eg: x + y = 1000 + 0100 = 1100. A simple rule is applied to avoid producing redundant expressions: Single-variable formulas are over x only

        Two-variable formulas are over x,y only

        Three-variable expressions are over x,y,z only

        Four-variable expressions are over x,y,z,w only

        This method returns the integer value of the number of variables in a FormulaTree (and thus whether the formula it represents is over x, or (x,y) or (x,y,z) or (x,y,z,w). Invalid range values (those not meeting the rule above) produce a return value of zero.

        Parameters:
        range - a byte expression for the variable range of a FormulaTree
        Returns:
        the integer number of variables in the FormulaTree, either 1, 2, 3, or 4, with invalid ranges returning zero.

      • unionRanges

        public static byte unionRanges(byte a,
               byte b)
        Union the range of two variable ranges
        Parameters:

        b - Java byte representing a variable range
        Returns:

        See Also:

      • updateRange

        public void updateRange()
        Update the variable range of a FormulaTree by Depth-First search. Updates are necessary when iteratively constructing larger FormulaTrees.

      • isInteresting

        public boolean isInteresting()
        Test if a formula is interesting. Call a formula interesting if:

        The outermost quantifier is universal and main connective is implication

        The outermost quantifier is existential and main connective is conjunction

        The outermost quantifier is uniqueness and main connective is conjunction

        Returns:
        true if interesting

      • value

        public boolean value(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> elements)
        //returns truth value for a formula over input domain elements /** Find the truth value of the expression represented by this FormulaTree over the input elements. Calls the recursive method valueRecurse().
        Parameters:
        elements - the elements of the input
        Returns:
        the truth value of the expression

      • valueRecurse

        public static boolean valueRecurse(FormulaTree t,
                   java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> elements,
                   java.util.Map<java.lang.Character,java.lang.String> substitution,
                   boolean debug)
        Recursive truth-value evaluation method for FormulaTrees. Tree nodes are either quantifiers, operators or predicates. Treat each case accordingly: quantifier cases: universal: check all substitutions (all possible substitutions of domain constants for this variable) return true if all true existential: check all substitutions, return true after first true case uniqueness: check all substitutions, return true if exactly one true operator cases (for subtrees A,B): conjunction: value(A & B) = value(A) && value(B) disjunction: value(A v B) = value(A) || value(B) implication: A -> B is equivalent to ¬A v B, so value(A -> B) = !(value(A)) || value(B) biconditional: A <-> B true if A and B have matching truth values, so value(A <-> B) = (value(A) == value(B)) negation: value(¬A) = !value(A) predicate case (base case): reach a predicate term of the form P(x,y,z), all predicate terms are leaves; by the time you reach a leaf, any variable terms will have been substituted away in the quantifier cases above. The substitution is a mapping between variables and domain elements, passed along as a parameter in the search routine, such as: (x |-> a, y |-> b, z |-> c). So return "true" if the tuple (a,b,c) appears in the fact table for P, return "false" otherwise.
        Parameters:
        t - a FormulaTree object
        elements - the domain elements
        substitution - a mapping of variable substitutions
        debug - debugging boolean
        Returns:
        the truth value of the formula
